(48) 22416th September, 1948CABINETINTERNATIONAL LABOUR CONFERENCE, GENEVA,JUNE-JULY, 1947Memorandum by the Minister of Labour and National service the concurrence of my colleagues is sought in the action which it isproposed that the Government should take in regard to a Convention and two recommendations adopted at the 30th Session of the International LabourConference. A report on this Conference (Geneva, 1947) was annexed to cp. (48) 133.2. Discussions have taken place between the various Departments primarily concerned on the action which should be taken in relation to the Convention(No. 81) and the Recommendations (Nos. 81 and 82), which concern LabourInspection. The texts of the Convention and Recommendations were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 7437. Authority is now sought for the issue of a white paper in the form of the attached draft, setting out the Government's decision in regard to them.3. I shall be putting forward proposals later concerning the five otherConventions adopted at the 30th Session of the Conference.G. A. I.Ministry of Labour and National Service,16th September, 1948ANNEXInternational Laeour conference draft White PaperTHERE are set out below the decisions of His Majesty's Government on aConvention and two Recommendations adopted by the International LabourConference at its 30th Session in 1947 which it is proposed to communicate to the Director-General of the International Labour Office. The English andFrench texts of the Convention and Recommendations were presented toParliament in Cmd. 7437.Convention (No. 81) concerning Labour Inspection in Industry and CommerceThis Convention provides for the organisation of labour inspection in industryand commerce. It allows for the exemption of mining and transport undertakings or parts of such undertakings from the application of the Convention, and forthe exclusion of labour inspection in commercial workplaces. His Majesty'sGovernment propose to accept the provisions of the Convention so far as they35899 relate to industry. His Majesty's Government also propose to apply the provisionsof the Convention to those parts of transport undertakings which are factories and to the loading and unloading of ships. They do not, however, propose atpresent to apply them to transport undertakings in general or to commerce.Legislation would be required if this were to be done; and labour inspection insuch cases is being considered by a Committee of Enquiry set up by His Majesty'sGovernment under the Chairmanship of Sir Ernest Gowers.The action indicated above.will enable His Majesty's Government to ratify the Convention and the necessary steps to this end will be taken as soon as possible.Recommendation (No. 81) concerning Labour InspectionThis Recommendation is supplementary to Convention No. 81. His Majesty'sGovernment do not propose to accept it as the proposals relative to the preventiveduties of labour inspectors appear to them to be in some respects objectionable.His Majesty's Government are, however, in agreement with the parts of theRecommendation as to the collaboration of employers and workers in regard to health and safety and as to labour disputes, and they would propose to haveregard to the provisions regarding the detailed information to be contained in annual reports on the work of inspection services.Recommendation (No. 82) concerning Labour Inspection in Mining and TransportU ndertakingsThis Recommendation applies where mining and transport undertakings areexempted from the application of Convention No. 81. His Majesty's government propose to accept the Recommendation to the extent to which the provisions ofConvention No. 81 will not at present be applied.
